I've generally slapped stuff together and launched it in the past but I fancy working this out properly for a change, can someone confirm if I'm doing this right? (some number are rounded so might not work out exactly here) 

 

I'm planning to put a Scansat & RemoteTech satellite in a 150km orbit of Duna.

Power requirement of the satellite is 5.72/sec if all sensors are running (I could use sensors individually and drop this to a maximum of 3.52 if needed).

According to the Inverse square law I think solar panels will generate approx.   13.62 / 21.82 = 39%, so I need the equivalent of 14.6 /s generation capability at Kerbin, which means at least 9  6x1 panels, or a Gigantor to keep it operating constantly.  The Gigantor would also mean it's generating enough power to run an Ion drive and DTS-M1 to get the orbit in the first place (needs 9.56/s), and I'm not taking in to account that they might be shaded by the probe at various times.

I plan to have it orbit at about 150km. This page tells me that v=sqrt(GxM/R), assuming G is real world I can get Duna's mass and radius from the Wiki and would expect to be orbiting at about sqrt(6.67E-11 x 4.52E21 / 500000) = 776 m/s. 

With a surface radius of 350km and an altitude of 150km I believe I should be in shade for about 2 x atan(350/500) = 70 degrees or about 20% of the orbit

Orbital distance of Pi x 2 x (150+350) =3141km at 776m/s is 4046 seconds, so in the dark for 20% of that is 809 seconds

So to keep everything running in the dark I need 809 x 5.72 = 4629 charge worth of batteries, which means carrying 5 Z1-K's.  Using only one sensor at a time would drop that to 2847 or 3 Z1-Ks

That 5000 charge would keep just the Ion engine and DTS-M1 running for 523 seconds even if it was in the dark, I'll need to check the dV that gives me I'd expect it to be plenty for the circularisation burn.

Does that seem right?

The calculations look good to me. A few things to consider about the physical situation, apart from the math:

You're going into a polar orbit, yes? In that case, the 809 seconds of darkness will just be the worst-case scenario for the least-favorable longitudes of AN/DN.  For most orientations, the dark period will be considerably less, or even zero. One of the benefits of a polar orbit.

You mention a DTS-M1 antenna. You need at least an 88-88 to reach home to Kerbin, unless you're relaying through something else nearby.

Your power requirement during the circularization burn is a bit lower than stated, because you can turn off your antenna while you're doing it.

The game only tracks electric consumption while you're actively flying the ship, so one easy (if exploity) way to get through the dark period is to just switch away to a different ship during that interval.

Oh crap, I'd read the DTS-M1 as 50Gm not 50Mm, well spotted   That'll up the power requirement a bit more then.

Yeah I figured I should plan for the worst case, if need by I can leave it with just the transmitter powered up when it's got the full darkness, but I'd rather not have to wait a few months to perform a scan. 

I've not got any other satellites out there to communicate with it on a lower powered antenna, so if I turn off the main antenna I won't be able to turn it back on again will I?

Looks like I need a bit of a redesign tonight then, current satellite doesn't have the communications range or the battery power to do the job.

I always use this tool when planning RemoteTech stuff. It's simply amazing.

Also, according to KSP wiki, these are your solar panel outputs at different distances:

5,263,138,304 6.68x Moho's semi-major axis
9,832,684,544 1.91x Eve's semi-major axis
13,599,840,256 1x Kerbin's orbit
20,726,155,264 0.431x Duna's semi-major axis
40,839,348,203 0.111x Dres's semi-major axis
68,773,560,320 0.0391x Jool's semi-major axis
90,118,820,000 0.0228x Eeloo's semi-major axis

Hope this helps

4 hours ago, RizzoTheRat said:

I've not got any other satellites out there to communicate with it on a lower powered antenna, so if I turn off the main antenna I won't be able to turn it back on again will I?

Use the RemoteTech flight computer,  it's your friend. It allows you to schedule actions to be taken in a fixed sequence at particular points in time, independently of whether you have communication or not.

For example, you're approaching the planet.  You feed your flight computer the following instructions:

  • Execute maneuver
  • Toggle antenna (time-delayed to happen 15 minutes after your maneuver)

...then, as you're approaching the planet's shadow, you send it an immediate-execute "Toggle antenna."

The ship will turn off its antenna (going dead to you, you're helpless now)... then it will execute the desired maneuver at the appropriate time... then 15 minutes later it turns its antenna back on and you're back in control.

This technique is also very handy when you need to aerobrake at a remote planet:  you want to retract your antenna while in atmosphere, so it doesn't get ripped off.

Of course, when you're engaging in such shenanigans, you need to be really careful not to make a careless "programming" error, or you could end up with a craft that's permanently uncontrolled.    There's a feeling of tense helplessness, waiting for control to come back... but actually, I kinda like that.  Gives you a tiny taste of what NASA engineers are feeling as their craft is in communications blackout during Martian reentry, and they're waiting / hoping / praying that the signal comes back when it turns the antennas on again...

One minor annoyance is that there's not actually any "toggle antenna" command for antennas.  They just have "activate" (which is available only while inactive) and "deactivate" (which is available only while active).  So there's no way in the KSP UI to send an "activate" command to an antenna that's already active.  So you need a workaround.  If you have more than one antenna, it's easy (you can deactivate one antenna, and send it a time-delayed "activate").  If you only have a single antenna, you can toggle it with an action group.  "Toggle" is an option as an action group in the VAB, just not as a UI action in the flight scene.  So you can put "toggle antenna" in an action group, and then you're good; you can use that action group in your queued commands.

 

Edited February 2, 2016 by Snark

5 hours ago, RizzoTheRat said:

I assumed that was just to add a manual delay on commands issued from the computer interface, are you saying you set the delay and then click on the antenna on the satellite and hit the activate/deactivate button?

Yes, that's exactly what I'm saying.  The manual delay applies to all commands sent to your craft-- that is, everything that goes through the "queued actions" in the flight computer UI and which is subject to lightspeed delay.

Note that there's a bit of subtlety here-- you need to send the "turn back on" command before you tell the antenna to shut down; because if you shut it down first, then it won't receive the turn-back-on command because it won't be listening, and you'll end up with an expensive Doorstop In Space.

So the typical sequence would be:

  1. Set a time delay
  2. Send the "turn on" command (unfortunately, you can't do this by clicking on the antenna, because it's already on and therefore its UI only has a "turn off" button; so you have to do this with an action group that is set to "toggle antenna" instead)
  3. Set the time delay back to zero (or, at least, something smaller)
  4. Send the "turn off" command (this time you can use the antenna itself, if you like)

 

Edited February 3, 2016 by Snark

11 minutes ago, RizzoTheRat said:

Interesting, that makes the whole flight computer business a lot more capable than I'd realised, thanks.

It really does.    The place where I find it most useful is aerobraking.  Unless you use the big, heavy, draggy, awkward fixed dishes (which I never do; they're just too painful), it's hard to do aerobraking in RemoteTech because your antennas get ripped off.  I've found that the delayed-command functionality of the flight computer is absolutely essential for that.  I can tell the antennas to temporarily deactivate for the time it takes the aerobraking to happen.

13 minutes ago, RizzoTheRat said:

I'll give it a go for future launches, unfortunately the current satellites are already orbit without any action groups set up.  Unless you're now going to tell me there's a way to set them up in flight?

Not in the stock game.  There are mods that let you do this (I've heard good things about Action Groups Extended, though I haven't used it myself).  Or you could hand-edit the save file; action groups are fairly simple, just find an example of a ship that does have an action group on it and copy that logic.  (Just make sure to keep a backup copy of the .sfs in case you munge something!)

There's a workaround that's possible in stock, but only if you have multiple antennas on the ship.  Let's say you have two antennas, A and B, both of which are capable of communicating back home to Kerbin, but normally you're only running A in order to save electricity.

(This is almost always the case with my own unmanned craft in RemoteTech, because the 88-88 is so small and light that it's no additional burden to put on a few "extras", and it gives me more operational flexibility-- for example, it allows me to use the satellite as a relay if I find the need to do so.  It's nice to have that option, even if at launch time I'm not actually planning to use it as a relay.)

In that case (where you have two antennas), you can send a delayed "turn on" command to B (which is possible, since it's already off), and then send your "turn off" command to A.  That way, you can accomplish the temporary antenna blackout without needing action groups.

If you have multiple satellites together, you can also work it if each one of them has a long-range antenna and a short-range omni, as long as they're close enough to be within omni range of each other.  In this case, antenna A is a long-range-to-Kerbin antenna, and antenna B is an omni that can reach the other satellite but not Kerbin.  In that case, you turn on B, turn off A (which is okay, because now your satellite is relaying through the other satellite via the omni), then send the delayed "turn on" signal to A, then you can turn off B.
